questions.text: A woman presents with dysuria and yellowish discharge. Gram staining shows gram-negative diplococci. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria

 

The presence of gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain is a classic finding in infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which is a sexually transmitted bacterium responsible for gonorrhea. Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically presents with symptoms such as dysuria (painful urination) and a yellowish or purulent discharge, which aligns with the clinical presentation described in the question.

 

Gram staining is a key diagnostic tool that helps differentiate bacterial species based on the characteristics of their cell walls. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus, meaning it appears as paired spherical bacteria that do not retain the crystal violet stain used in gram staining but do take up the counterstain, appearing pink or red under a microscope.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Trichomoniasis: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis, which is a flagellated organism. While trichomoniasis can cause dysuria and yellowish discharge, it would not present with gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain. If the organism had flagella, Trichomoniasis would be a consideration, but the gram stain findings rule it out.

 

Option C. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis is another sexually transmitted bacterium that can cause symptoms similar to those of gonorrhea. However, it does not appear as gram-negative diplococci on gram stain. Instead, it is typically detected by nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT).

 

Option D. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is characterized by an imbalance in the vaginal flora and typically diagnosed using Amsel's criteria or by identifying clue cells on microscopy. It is not associated with gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of gram-negative diplococci in a patient with dysuria and yellowish discharge is highly indicative of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, a common cause of gonorrhea

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with redness and pain in the eye. Examination revealed an IOP of 38 mm of Hg, aqueous flare, and corneal precipitates. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in her? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prostaglandin analogs

 

  • The clinical vignette suggests anterior uveitis with a raised intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues like latanoprost increase uveoscleral outflow and lower intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues act by stimulating prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases that increase uveoscleral outflow.
  • Prostaglandin analogues should be used with caution in patients with uveitis, iritis, cystoid macular edema, and herpes simplex keratitis.
  • Prostaglandin analogues are the least suited for use in this patient as they can worsen the anterior uveitis.
  • PG Analogues can also cause cystoids macular edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: These are generally safe in uveitis unless contraindicated for systemic reasons.

 

Option B. Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic can be used for quick reduction of IOP in acute settings but does not exacerbate uveitis.

 

Option C. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: Also safe for use in reducing IOP in uveitis, unless systemic contraindications exist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with anterior uveitis and high IOP, prostaglandin analogs should be avoided due to their potential to worsen intraocular inflammation and the risk of inducing or exacerbating cystoid macular edema. Other options such as beta blockers, mannitol, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors can be considered based on the individual patient's overall health and specific eye condition.

choices.text: Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment
Prevalence is 7 -10 percent in general population

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Depression is a common comorbidity

 

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a condition characterized by intrusive, repetitive thoughts (obsessions) and the urge to perform repetitive behaviors or rituals (compulsions).

 

Many individuals with OCD also suffer from depression. The two conditions can coexist and may even be related in some manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atypical antipsychotics is the first line treatment: This is false. The first-line treatments for OCD are selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), clomipramine and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Atypical antipsychotics may be added as an adjunctive treatment in patients who do not respond to standard treatments.

 

Option B. Prevalence is 7-10 percent in general population: This is incorrect. The prevalence of OCD in the general population is around 2-3%.

 

Option D. Contamination is an uncommon obsession: False. Contamination obsessions are the most common types of obsessions in OCD. Individuals may fear germs or becoming ill and may wash their hands excessively as a result.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OCD is characterized by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3% and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 95-97.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the clinic with erythematous lesions over the exposed areas of the skin like hands, arms, chest, etc. She also complains of arthralgia and breathlessness. Which among the following antibodies will be useful in diagnosing this condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-dsDNA antibodies

 

The patient exhibits symptoms including erythematous lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin, arthralgia, and breathlessness, which are characteristic of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). The rash described is typical of an SLE rash and not dermatomyositis, which presents with rashes over the knuckles known as Gottron's papules.

 

For diagnosing SLE, anti-dsDNA antibodies are very useful due to their high specificity. Although their sensitivity is relatively low (30-50%), the specificity is very high (>90-95%), making them reliable markers for confirming the diagnosis of SLE. Anti-dsDNA antibodies are also associated with disease activity in SLE.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antihistone antibodies: These are primarily associated with drug-induced lupus erythematosus, not classic SLE.

 

Option C. Anticentromere antibodies: These are typically seen in limited forms of scleroderma, particularly CREST syndrome, and are not associated with SLE.

 

Option D. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): While ANA is a good initial screening test for SLE due to its high sensitivity, it lacks specificity. ANA can be positive in a variety of autoimmune conditions, thus it is not as specific as anti-dsDNA antibodies for diagnosing SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for diagnosing Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), despite their moderate sensitivity.

questions.text: Identify the device in the image: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PEG tube

 

The image provided shows a tray containing various instruments, including an introducer, a tube with a bolster, and a guide wire, which are characteristic of a PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube kit. A PEG tube is used for providing nutrition directly into the stomach in patients who cannot swallow food. The distinguishing features of a PEG tube include a retention bolster that secures the tube to the abdominal wall and an inflatable balloon at the end that helps retain the tube within the stomach. The presence of these components in the tray confirms that the  is a PEG tube. This procedure involves making a small incision in the abdomen, inserting the tube, and securing it, which is why the tray includes various tools for this process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NJ tube (Nasojejunal tube): An NJ tube is inserted through the nose and extends into the jejunum. It is typically used for feeding but does not require the surgical kit or bolster shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. NG tube (Nasogastric tube): An NG tube is a simple tube inserted through the nose into the stomach or intestine. Unlike the PEG tube, it does not involve a retention bolster or a complex insertion procedure, making it less likely to require the tools seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Chest drain tube: A chest drain tube is used to remove air, fluid, or pus from the pleural space in the chest. It typically does not include the bolster and balloon characteristic of a PEG tube, and the tools in the image do not match those used for chest drainage procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The PEG tube is a specialized device used for long-term feeding directly into the stomach, identified by its retention bolster and the presence of specific tools in the insertion kit. Understanding the key components of the PEG tube kit helps differentiate it from other types of medical tubes

questions.text: A young man, aged 25, arrived with complaints of being unable to bend the distal interphalangeal joint of his 4th and 5th fingers. Additionally, he faced difficulty in gripping a piece of paper between his fingers. Where is the probable location of the injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

  • The given clinical scenario depicts paralysis of medial 2 lumbricals and palmar interossei which are supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • Ulnar nerve lies behind medial epicondyle, marked as C in the given image.
  • Ulnar nerve supplies Flexor carpi ulnaris & medial half of flexor digitorum profundus in forearm and in hand, it gives motor supply to hypothenar muscles, adductor pollicis, all interossei and medial two lumbricals.

 

ULNAR NERVE PALSY

 

  1. High ulnar nerve palsy (Injury proximal to elbow): Paralysis of all muscles supplied ulnar nerve in forearm and hand. Sensory deficit in the skin of hand.
  2. Low ulnar nerve palsy (Injury distal one third of forearm): Sparing of forearm muscles, Paralysis of hand muscles. Sensory deficit in the skin of hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The structure marked as A is the deltoid tuberosity. Injury to this part is rare. Its superficial location places it at a risk of trauma, fracture, and sequestration.

 

Option B. The structure marked as B is the lateral epicondyle. The lateral epicondyle is usually involved in the lateral epicondylitis or tennis elbow i.e., the overuse injury secondary to the eccentric overload of the common extensor tendon at the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) tendon.

 

Option D. The structure marked as D is the anatomical neck of humerus. Here, the shoulder joint capsule is attached. Injury to this part is highly uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The marked structure C is the medial epicondyle. The Ulnar nerve passes from behind the epicondyle. Injury to the ulnar nerve at this area causes ulnar claw hand i.e., the extension of IP joints of 4th and 5th fingers; along with weakness in grip of the hand.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with a satellite skin lesion. On examination, the patient has one hypopigmented lesion and one thickened nerve. The images of two blister packs are provided. Based on the WHO / NLEP Guidelines, which treatment is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Answer:

The correct answer is B. Packet 2 for 12 months.

Latest Guidelines for Leprosy: NLEP = WHO (from April 1, 2025)

As of April 1, 2025, India's NLEP has aligned completely with WHO guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of leprosy. This means that the same criteria and drug regimens are now followed globally and in India.

 

*If a case has any one of the three features suggestive of MB, he/she is classified as MB.

 

Treatment Regimen: WHO & NLEP (Post April 1st 2025)

 

Other Options:

Option A: Packet 1 for 12 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option C: Packet 1 for 6 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option D Packet 2 for 6 months: 

Although Packet 2 contains the correct medications, the treatment duration of 6 months is insufficient for multibacillary leprosy according to WHO guidelines, which recommends 12 months.

 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to diagnose Leprosy 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to treat Leprosy 

OLD PB MDT with 2 drugs followed by NLEP:

 

Educational objective:

  • As of April 1, 2025, NLEP follows WHO guidelines for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • Classification is based on skin lesions, nerve involvement, and skin smear.
  • For a patient with multibacillary leprosy, characterized by one or more thickened nerves and multiple skin lesions, the appropriate treatment is with a regimen containing rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone (Packet 2) for a duration of 12 months.

 

References:

Jopling’s handbook of leprosy, 6th edition, page no 10

Andrew’s diseases of the skin: clinical dermatology 13th edition page no 338, 339, 345

questions.text: All of the options listed can be utilized for assessing data normalcy except? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mantel-Haenszel test

 

  • The Mantel Haenszel test is used for sample sets that are able to be placed in two by two tables, but unlike the Fisher Exact test and the chi-squared test, there is no “n” requirement.
  • Normality of a data refers to a specific statistical distribution called a normal distribution, or sometimes the Gaussian distribution or bell-shaped curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plot histogram: Correct for assessing data normalcy. A histogram can visually show whether data follow a normal distribution.

 

Option C. Box whisker: Correct for assessing data normalcy. A box-and-whisker plot (box plot) can reveal the symmetry and spread of data, indicating normality.

 

Option D. Shapiro Wilk test: Correct for assessing data normalcy. The Shapiro-Wilk test is a statistical test specifically designed to test the normality of data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mantel-Haenszel test is not used for assessing the normality of data. Normality can be assessed using tools like plot histograms, box-and-whisker plots, Shapiro-Wilk test, Kolmogorov–Smirnov test, etc.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with left facial weakness. Routine lab workup was normal. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corticosteroids

 

The presentation of left facial weakness with normal routine lab workup suggests Bell's palsy, an idiopathic condition characterized by sudden onset of unilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion and is the most common cause of unilateral facial paralysis.

 

Corticosteroids: The first-line treatment for Bell's palsy is corticosteroids. They are most effective when started within 72 hours of symptom onset. Early treatment with corticosteroids can significantly improve the chances of complete recovery. A typical regimen is prednisolone or prednisone.

 

Dosage: Prednisone 60-80 mg per day for 5-7 days, followed by a taper over the next 5-7 days.

 

Note – In the severity grading system, House-Brackmann grading, if the patient has Grade 4 or Grade 5 severity, consider adding antivirals such as acyclovir or valacyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: Although acyclovir or other antiviral agents like valacyclovir are sometimes used, their benefit is less clear. They may be considered in severe cases of Bell's palsy, particularly when there is a suspicion of herpes simplex virus involvement, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Dosage: Valacyclovir 1 gram TID for 7 days or acyclovir 400 mg five times a day for 7-10 days.

 

Note - Valacyclovir has superior bioavailability, superior efficacy, and lower side effects compared to acyclovir.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: There is no role for antibiotics in the treatment of Bell's palsy as it is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Option D. Physiotherapy: While physiotherapy, including facial exercises and eye protection measures, can be supportive, it is not the primary treatment and should be considered an adjunct to corticosteroid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best initial management for a patient with Bell's palsy is corticosteroid therapy. Early administration within 72 hours of symptom onset greatly enhances the likelihood of complete recovery. Antivirals may be added in severe cases, but they are not the mainstay of treatment.

choices.text: Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release
Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release

questions.text: A 45-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasm with arching of his back as shown in the image, a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The toxin responsible for this type of abnormal posturing acts by which of the following mechanisms? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presynaptic inhibition of GABA and glycine release

 

This abnormal posturing is caused by tetanospasmin which is produced by clostridium tetani. It inhibits presynaptic GABA and glycine release.

 

 

Clostridium tetani is an obligate anaerobic, gram-positive bacillus with terminal round spore (drumstick appearance).

 

Tetanus is manifested by skeletal muscle spasms and autonomic nervous system disturbance. Tetanus only affects skeletal muscle, smooth muscle, and cardiac muscle function normally.

 

C. tetani produces two exotoxins–tetanolysin and tetanospasmin.

 

  1. Tetanolysin is a heat-labile, oxygen-labile hemolysin antigenically related to the oxygen-labile hemolysins produced by C. perfringens, S. pyogenes, and S. pneumoniae. Tetanolysin damages otherwise viable tissue surrounding the infection and optimizes the conditions for bacterial multiplication.
  2. Tetanospasmin (or tetanus toxin) is a heat-labile, oxygen-stable, plasmid-coded neurotoxin responsible for disease manifestations. Tetanus neurotoxin is released upon cell lysis after bacterial growth under anaerobic conditions (e.g., in deep puncture wounds). It is antigenic and is specifically neutralized by its antitoxin. Its toxoid form is used for vaccine preparation.

 

Mechanism of Tetanus Toxin-

 

Tetanus toxin binds to polysialogangliosides receptors present on motor nerve terminals which results in toxin internalization.

 

Following internalization, tetanus toxin gets transported in a retrograde way from the peripheral nervous system to the central nervous system by retrograde axonal transport. When tetanus toxin reaches inhibitory neuron terminals, it prevents the presynaptic release of inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).

 

Incubation period of tetanus is about 6-10 days.

 

 

Clinical features - Patients have prolonged muscle spasms of both flexor and extensor muscles. Patients with tetanus have spastic muscle contractions, difficulty opening the jaw (called lockjaw, “trismus”), a characteristic smile called “risus sardonicus” and contractions of back muscles resulting in backward arching (Opisthotonos position). Patients are extremely irritable, and tetanic seizures develop, brought about by violent, painful muscle contractions following some minor stimulus, such as noise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presynaptic inhibition of Ach receptors: This mechanism is not involved in the action of tetanospasmin. It is more relevant to the action of botulinum toxin.

 

Option C. Postsynaptic inhibition of GABA: This is not the mechanism of action for tetanospasmin. Tetanospasmin acts presynaptically.

 

Option D. Cleavage of SNARE proteins, preventing Ach release: This describes the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin, not tetanospasmin. Botulinum toxin cleaves SNARE proteins, which prevents the release of acetylcholine (Ach) at the neuromuscular junction, leading to flaccid paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetanospasmin, the toxin responsible for tetanus, acts by inhibiting the presynaptic release of the inhibitory neurotransmitters GABA and glycine, leading to unopposed muscle contraction and the characteristic symptoms of tetanus, such as muscle spasms and opisthotonos.

questions.text: A woman, 35 years old, arrives with symptoms of skin thickening, weakened muscles, and paleness in the extremities when exposed to cold temperatures. Her ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibody tests yield positive results. Elevated levels of creatinine kinase are observed, and a muscle biopsy reveals perifascicular infiltration. Which antibody is linked to these findings? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibody

 

The given patient presenting symptoms that indicate diffuse systemic sclerosis and dermatomyositis/polymyositis, is highly probable to have an overlap syndrome [Combinations of three connective tissue diseases, i.e., systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS) and polymyositis (PM) or dermatomyositis (DM)].

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are characteristically found in patients with overlap syndromes, which involve features of systemic sclerosis combined with polymyositis or dermatomyositis. These overlap syndromes involve a combination of autoimmune conditions, often including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), progressive systemic sclerosis (PSS), and polymyositis (PM) or dermatomyositis (DM).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-U3 RNP: Anti-U3 RNP antibodies are typically associated with systemic sclerosis but can be found in both limited and diffuse forms of the disease. They are not specifically linked to the overlap syndrome seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Anti-centromere antibody: Anti-centromere antibodies are most commonly associated with limited systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome), not the diffuse form or the overlap syndrome involving myositis.

 

Option D. Anti-Jo-1 antibody: Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are strongly associated with polymyositis and dermatomyositis, particularly with lung involvement, but they are less common than Anti-PM-Scl antibodies in patients with overlap syndromes involving systemic sclerosis and myositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibodies are commonly associated with overlap syndromes involving systemic sclerosis and myositis, making them the likely antibody in patients presenting with features of both conditions.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old chronic smoker presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and cough. A mass is noted at the lower lobe periphery of the lung. A diagnosis of lung adenocarcinoma is made. What will be the biopsy finding? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Thyroid transcription factor-1
  2. P40
  3. Napsin A
  4. Chromogranin
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3

 

In the context of lung adenocarcinoma, particularly in a chronic smoker presenting with a peripheral lung mass, specific markers on the biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.

 

1. Thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1): TTF-1 is a nuclear transcription factor commonly expressed in lung adenocarcinoma and is used as a diagnostic marker to differentiate primary lung adenocarcinoma from other types of lung cancer.

 

3. Napsin A: Napsin A is another marker often expressed in lung adenocarcinoma, associated with the protein's role in the proteolytic processing of surfactant precursors in the lung.

 

These markers are both used to identify lung adenocarcinoma, particularly in cases where the tumor presents in the lung periphery.

 

Other options:

 

2. P40: P40 is a marker associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, not adenocarcinoma. Its presence would suggest a different subtype of lung cancer.

 

4. Chromogranin: Chromogranin is a marker used in neuroendocrine tumors, such as small cell lung cancer, and is not typically found in lung adenocarcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
The fibres of the internal oblique muscle and transversus abdominus muscle contribute to which boundaries of the inguinal canal walls? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Anterior wall
  2. Roof
  3. Floor
  4. Posterior wall
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ii and iv

 

 

 

The inguinal canal is an important structure in the anterior abdominal wall, with specific boundaries formed by different layers of muscles and fascia. The internal oblique is present in the lateral 1/3rd of anterior wall but transverse abdominis does not contribute to the anterior wall at all.

 

ii. Roof: The fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, along with their conjoint tendon, form the roof of the inguinal canal.

 

iv. Posterior wall: The conjoint tendon, formed by the joining of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles, also contributes to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

i. Anterior wall: The anterior wall of the inguinal canal is primarily formed by the external oblique aponeurosis, along with skin and superficial fascia. The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles do not contribute to the anterior wall.

 

iii. Floor: The floor of the inguinal canal is formed by the inguinal ligament, not by the internal oblique or transversus abdominis muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles contribute to the roof and posterior wall of the inguinal canal through their conjoint tendon.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

Mitochondrial inheritance (A) is associated with Leber's disease (3). Mitochondrial inheritance, also called maternal inheritance, occurs when DNA in the mitochondria is passed from mother to offspring. Leber's optic neuropathy is a classic example of a mitochondrial disease transmitted through maternal inheritance. This is because mitochondrial DNA is present in the ovum but not in sperm.

 

 

X-linked recessive inheritance (B) is linked to Duchene's muscular dystrophy (4). In XLR inheritance, the disease is more common in males since they only have one X chromosome. Duchene's muscular dystrophy is specifically listed as an example of X-linked recessive disorders.

 

Autosomal recessive inheritance (C) corresponds to cystic fibrosis (2). AR disorders require two copies of the mutated gene to manifest the disease and are common in consanguineous marriages. Cystic fibrosis is a classic example of an autosomal recessive disorder affecting enzymatic proteins.

 

Trinucleotide repeat disorders (D) include spinobulbar dystrophy (1). These disorders are characterized by expansion of nucleotide repeats during gametogenesis, leading to neurological diseases. The unstable expansion of trinucleotide repeats (CAG) causes spinobulbar muscular atrophy (Kennedy disease).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Genetic Disorders and Their Inheritance Patterns

choices.text: Pap smear
Visual inspection with iodine

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension came with post-menopausal bleeding. Which of the following you will do to evaluate the cause? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endometrial sampling

 

  • Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.
  • Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is a better first-line investigation since TVS is not included in the options, endometrial sampling is the next best answer.
  • Both diabetes and hypertension are risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma hence endometrial sampling would be the more appropriate test as compared to tests for cervical cancer screening.
  • Endometrial sampling is indicated in a woman with post-menopausal bleeding with the endometrial thickness is > 4 mm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pap smear: A pap smear should be done in all women complaining of post menopausal women with a normal looking cervix and a cervical biopsy for all women with a cervical growth but in this question, based on risk factors, we are more worried about endometrial cancer and hence endometrial sampling is a better option.

 

Option B. Visual inspection with iodine: This is not the preferred option and even if cervical cancer screening is warranted, a pap smear or HPV is better.

 

Option C. Colposcopy: This is indicated if there is any cytological abnormality on the pap smear

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometrial sampling is done to evaluate a patient presenting with postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Ref: Page no 560, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain and discomfort for the past few months. The patient also reported experiencing weight loss and loss of appetite. On evaluation, a mass is palpable in the upper abdomen, and an endoscopy shows an ulcerated lesion in the stomach. A biopsy of the lesion is taken and sent for immunohistochemistry. The biopsy sample is found to be positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100. Based on these findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GIST

 

The clinical presentation and the biopsy results suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST). GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen, and it typically arises from the interstitial cells of Cajal or the pacemaker cells of the gastrointestinal muscularis propria. GISTs are often associated with symptoms of mass effect, such as abdominal pain and discomfort, and can lead to weight loss and loss of appetite. The diagnosis of GIST is confirmed by immunohistochemistry, which typically shows positivity for KIT (CD117) detectable in Cajal cells. Other immunohistochemical markers such as LCA, cytokeratin, and S100 are negative. Treatment options for GIST may include surgery, radiation therapy, or targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma is a common type of cancer that can occur in various organs, including the stomach. However, the immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (positive for CD117 and negative for LCA, cytokeratin, and S100) are not characteristic of adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Hodgkin’s lymphoma: Hodgkin's lymphoma is a type of lymphoma that typically presents with enlarged lymph nodes and is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question are not consistent with Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma is commonly associated with the epithelial lining of organs, and its diagnosis would typically involve positive staining for cytokeratin. The immunohistochemistry findings mentioned in the question (negative for cytokeratin) do not support the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GISTs are mesenchymal tumors that typically occur in the gastrointestinal tract. They often express CD117 (c-kit), a marker commonly associated with GIST. The negative staining for LCA (Leukocyte Common Antigen), cytokeratin, and S100 helps rule out other possibilities and supports the diagnosis of GIST.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease, also known as Graves' ophthalmopathy. This condition is associated with autoimmune thyroid disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the tissues around the eyes, leading to inflammation and swelling. This results in the characteristic bulging of the eyes, known as proptosis or exophthalmos.

 

Thyroid eye disease is particularly common in middle-aged individuals and can cause both unilateral (one eye) and bilateral (both eyes) proptosis. The pathophysiology involves the expansion of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, leading to the protrusion of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft tissue tumour in orbit: While soft tissue tumors in the orbit can cause proptosis, they are not the most common cause in middle-aged individuals. These tumors can be benign or malignant and require imaging studies for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Optic nerve meningioma: This type of tumor is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and can lead to proptosis. However, it is less common compared to thyroid eye disease.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Although cavernous hemangioma is the most common orbital tumor in adults, it is not the most common cause of proptosis. These benign vascular tumors can cause proptosis if they become large enough to displace the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease (Graves' ophthalmopathy).

questions.text:
First part of PCT has which of the following transport proteins? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Sodium potassium pump
  2. Na- glucose co-transporter
  3. Sodium hydrogen antiport
  4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1,2,3

 

1. Sodium-potassium pump: This transporter is found on the basolateral side of the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) cells and is critical for maintaining the sodium gradient that drives other transport processes.

 

2. Na-glucose co-transporter: This is located on the apical membrane of PCT cells and uses the sodium gradient to co-transport glucose from the tubular lumen into the cell.

 

3. Sodium-hydrogen antiport: Also on the apical membrane, this antiporter exchanges sodium from the tubular lumen with hydrogen ions from the cell, playing a key role in sodium reabsorption and pH balance.

 

Other Option

 

4. Na+ Bicarbonate cotransporter: It is present in the distal or late part of PCT (Not in the early PCT)- contributes to bicarbonate reabsorption.

The correct combination based on the provided answer is b) 1,2,3, which includes the sodium-potassium pump, the Na-glucose co-transporter, and the sodium-hydrogen antiport, all of which are essential for the function of the PCT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proximal convoluted tubule – transport processes –

choices.text: Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months
Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months of starting primary therapy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the treatment of recurrent ovarian cancer? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months  of starting primary therapy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Platinum-refractory disease: This includes women who progress during primary chemotherapy. It has the worst prognosis, as these patients do not respond to platinum-based chemotherapy at all.
  • Platinum-resistant disease: This includes women who relapse within 6 months of completing primary therapy. Bevacizumab has been approved for the treatment of platinum-resistant disease due to its ability to inhibit angiogenesis, which is crucial for tumor growth and metastasis.
  • Platinum-sensitive disease: This includes women who relapse more than 6 months after completing primary therapy. These patients are considered to have a better prognosis and are treated with a platinum-based combination such as carboplatin and paclitaxel or gemcitabine.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Platinum resistant if recurrence > 12 months: This statement is incorrect. If the recurrence occurs more than 12 months after treatment, it is considered platinum-sensitive, not resistant.

 

Option B. Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months: This statement is not a recognized classification. The classification focuses on the 6-month mark to distinguish between resistant and sensitive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Platinum-sensitive recurrent ovarian cancer is characterized by a recurrence occurring more than 6 months after completing primary therapy.

 

 

Ref: Berek and Novak’s gynecology 15th edition pg 1387

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presented with an acute onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm and diaphoresis. His ECG and cardiac biomarkers show non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following will be used in the treatment of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

1. Atorvastatin 

2. Aspirin 

3. Clopidogrel 

4. Low molecular weight heparin 

5. Alteplase
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:  

 

In the management of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), several medications are routinely used to reduce the risk of further ischemic events and manage the condition effectively:

 

  1. Atorvastatin: High-intensity statin therapy is recommended to lower cholesterol levels and stabilize atherosclerotic plaques.
  2. Aspirin: This antiplatelet agent is essential for reducing clot formation and preventing further arterial blockage.
  3. Clopidogrel: Another antiplatelet agent, often used in combination with aspirin, to provide dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), which is beneficial in preventing further ischemic events.
  4. Low molecular weight heparin: Anticoagulant therapy, such as enoxaparin, is crucial in preventing thrombus formation and managing NSTEMI. Enoxaparin is typically administered subcutaneously at a dose of 1 mg/kg twice daily.

 

Other Option:

 

5. Alteplase: This thrombolytic agent is used in the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is not immediately available. It is not indicated for NSTEMI due to the lack of ST elevation and the associated risks of bleeding without significant benefit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For NSTEMI management, the treatment includes Atorvastatin, Aspirin, Clopidogrel, and Low molecular weight heparin. Thrombolytic agents like Alteplase are reserved for STEMI with specific indications.

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

1-b: Colour vision - Ishihara chart:

 

Colour vision is tested with Ishihara plates, which is a pseudoisochromatic chart. There are patterns of coloured and grey dots that reveal one pattern to persons with normal colour vision and another to those with the colour deficiency.

 

The below image shows a representative plate of the Ishihara chart.

 

 

Limitation of ischihara chart: Ischihara chart is useful as a screening tool for colour blindness. It mainly tests for red-green blindness.

 

In order to check blue-yellow blindness other tests such as 100 Hue Test are required.

 

2-a: Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer:

 

An applanation tonometer is used to measure the intraocular pressure. It is based on the Imbert-Fick law, which states that the pressure inside a sphere(P) is equal to the force (W) required to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening (A).

 

P = W/A

 

The following is an image of the applanation tonometer:

 

 

There are two types of applanation tonometers:

 

(1) In which the surface area of the prism is constant – Eg

 

  1. Goldmann Applanation Tonometer (GAT):
    • The Goldmann tonometer is one of the most widely used and considered the gold standard for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It consists of a prism that is gently applied to the anesthetized cornea, flattening a small area.
    • The amount of force required to flatten the cornea is directly related to intraocular pressure.
  2. Perkins Applanation Tonometer:
    • The Perkins tonometer is a handheld, portable device used for measuring intraocular pressure.
    • It is similar in principle to the Goldmann tonometer but is more compact and easier to transport.
  3. Tono-Pen (Reichert Tonometer):
    • The Tono-Pen is a handheld electronic applanation tonometer.
    • It works by measuring the force required to flatten the cornea, and the reading is displayed electronically.
    • It is often used in clinical settings due to its ease of use and portability.

 

(2) Tonometer with constant pressure and variable area – eg. MALAKOFF’S Tonometer.

 

3-d: Peripheral vision - Perimetry:

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic procedure used to chart the boundaries of a person's visual field. There are two main types of perimetry: kinetic and static perimetry. Kinetic perimetry involves moving a target with a specific luminance from a non-seeing area in the periphery towards the center until the person perceives it. In contrast, static perimetry involves presenting a stationary stimulus and adjusting its intensity until the person either reaches a threshold of detection or can no longer detect it. One type of static perimetry is tangent screen perimetry, which tests the central 30 degrees field at 1 meter and evaluates a person's central vision.

 

Examples of Kinetic Perimetry – Goldmann perimetry and Bjerrum Perimetry

 

Examples of Static Perimetry – Static Automated perimetry – Humphrey Visual Field analyser and Octopus Visual field analyser.

 

4-c: Central vision - Tangent screen test:

 

The tangent screen test is a specific method used to assess central visual field up to 30 degrees from fixation. It involves using a black screen and white or colored targets to determine the sensitivity of central vision, particularly useful in detecting central visual field defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Colour vision - Ishihara chart
  • Intraocular pressure - Applanation tonometer
  • Peripheral vision - Perimetry
  • Central vision - Tangent screen test

choices.text: Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length pair technique
RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

questions.text: Which of the following is more appropriate for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genome?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RTPCR followed by Real time PCR

 

RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

 

To quantitatively analyze viral RNA genomes, two key processes are required:

 

  1. Reverse Transcription (RT): Viral RNA must first be converted into complementary DNA (cDNA) because PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) can only amplify DNA. This is done using Reverse Transcriptase, hence RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR).
  2. Quantification using Real Time PCR (qPCR): Once the cDNA is synthesized, Real-Time PCR is used to quantify the amount of target nucleic acid in real time using fluorescent markers.

 

 

Thus, for quantitative analysis of viral RNA:
 

  • First step → RT-PCR
  • Second step → Real-Time PCR (qPCR)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Real Time PCR: This refers to quantification but only works with DNA, not directly with RNA. Without the reverse transcription step, it cannot quantify viral RNA.
 

Option B. Conventional PCR with RFLP: This is qualitative and used for genotyping or mutation detection, not quantitative analysis.
 

Option C. RT-PCR: RT-PCR alone allows detection of RNA (qualitative), but not quantification unless combined with Real-Time PCR.

 

Educational Objective:


RT PCR followed by Real-time PCR is the most appropriate technique for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes, allowing real-time monitoring and quantification of viral RNA load.

choices.text: Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a family history of breast and ovarian cancer is seeking advice about her risk for developing breast cancer. She is currently taking oral contraceptive pills and is concerned about her risk. Which of the following is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Genetic counselling and screening for BRA

 

  • A family history of breast and ovarian cancer in close relatives with one of the relatives having an onset before the age of 50 years indicates a high risk for breast cancer.
  • The next step in management is genetic counselling and screening for BRA.
  • This involves discussing various genetic testing options such as BRCA testing and multiple gene panel testing.
  • Genetic testing is recommended for high-risk women with a family history of breast or ovarian cancer, particularly if the diagnosis was made before age 50, if there are multiple affected family members, or if the patient has a personal history of breast or ovarian cancer.
  • Mammography is not the initial investigation of choice but can be used for surveillance after genetic screening.
  • Discontinuing oral contraceptive pills is not necessary as they do not increase the risk of breast cancer in women with a positive family history of breast cancer.

 

Given the patient's family history of breast and ovarian cancer, as well as her concerns about her risk, the next best step is to offer genetic counseling and testing for BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations. These genetic mutations are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancer. Understanding her genetic risk can help the patient make informed decisions about her healthcare, including potential surveillance and risk-reduction strategies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Routine mammography: Routine mammography is a screening tool for breast cancer, but it is typically recommended for women starting at around age 40 or 50, depending on guidelines and individual risk factors. While it's an important part of breast cancer screening, it may not be the most appropriate initial step in this case, given the patient's family history and concerns.

 

Option C. Stop taking oral contraceptive pills: While hormonal factors can be associated with a slight increase in breast cancer risk, discontinuing oral contraceptive pills may not be the primary step in managing a patient with a strong family history of breast and ovarian cancer. Genetic counseling and testing for BRCA mutations would provide more specific information about her risk.

 

Option D. Prophylactic surgery: Prophylactic surgery, such as a bilateral mastectomy or oophorectomy, may be considered in individuals with known BRCA mutations who have a high risk of breast and ovarian cancer. However, this step would be taken after genetic counseling and testing to determine the patient's risk and suitability for such procedures. It is not the initial step in management.

choices.text: Reed Sternberg cells are of B cell origin
Reed Sternberg cells are CD30+ and PAX 5+
Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum
Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) ? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring

 

Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) is characterized by the presence of Reed Sternberg cells, which are of B cell origin. These cells typically express CD30 and PAX 5 markers. The nodular sclerosis subtype of HL often involves the mediastinum, where Reed Sternberg cells are referred to as lacunar cells due to their unique appearance in this subtype. However, the statement that the commonest site for HL is the Waldeyer ring is incorrect. The Waldeyer ring is more commonly involved in non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). HL typically affects the cervical, mediastinal, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reed Sternberg cells are of B cell origin: Correct. Reed Sternberg cells, the hallmark of Hodgkin lymphoma, originate from B cells.

 

Option B. Reed Sternberg cells are CD30+ and PAX 5+: Correct. Reed Sternberg cells express CD30 and PAX 5 markers, which are used in diagnosing Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option C. Nodular sclerosis HL commonly involves the mediastinum: Correct. The nodular sclerosis subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma frequently involves the mediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hodgkin lymphoma typically involves the cervical, mediastinal, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes. The involvement of the Waldeyer ring is more characteristic of non-Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: What is the stage of sleep denoted by the arrow: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM

 

Explanation:

 

The stage of sleep indicated by the arrow is REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. This can be identified based on the specific patterns observed in the EEG (Electroencephalogram), EMG (Electromyogram), and EOG (Electrooculogram) readings:

 

 

 

  • EEG: The EEG during REM sleep shows low-amplitude, high-frequency waves that are similar to the wakeful state. This pattern is characteristic of REM sleep and is often described as "sawtooth" waves.
  • EMG: The EMG during REM sleep shows a flat line, indicating muscle atonia. This muscle atonia is a defining feature of REM sleep, where most of the body's voluntary muscles are temporarily paralyzed. This prevents the sleeper from acting out their dreams.
  • EOG: The EOG during REM sleep shows rapid movements of the eyes, which is where REM sleep gets its name. These rapid eye movements are indicative of the intense brain activity occurring during this stage, despite the body's overall lack of movement.

 

In contrast, non-REM (NREM) sleep stages (including NREM 2, 3, and 4) show different patterns:

 

  • NREM stages generally have higher amplitude, lower frequency EEG patterns.
  • Muscle tone is reduced but not absent as in REM sleep.
  • Eye movements are either slow or absent, depending on the specific NREM stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NREM 2: This stage of sleep is characterized by sleep spindles and K-complexes on the EEG, with reduced but not absent muscle tone and minimal eye movement. The patterns described in the question do not match this stage.

 

Option B. NREM 3: Known as slow-wave sleep or deep sleep, NREM 3 is characterized by high-amplitude, low-frequency delta waves on the EEG. Muscle tone is decreased but not completely absent, and there is minimal to no eye movement. The pattern described does not correspond to NREM 3.

 

Option C. NREM 4: Often combined with NREM 3 in the modern classification, this stage is also characterized by delta waves, reduced muscle tone, and lack of eye movement. The described pattern is inconsistent with this stage as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

REM sleep is characterized by low-amplitude, high-frequency EEG waves, muscle atonia as shown in the EMG, and rapid eye movements as shown in the EOG. Recognizing these patterns is crucial for correctly identifying REM sleep, which is a critical stage for processes like memory consolidation and emotional regulation.

questions.text: High anion gap acidosis with low bicarbonate levels is seen in all the following conditions except: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal Disorders

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is characterized by the accumulation of acids in the body, which are not accompanied by an increase in other measured anions, thus increasing the anion gap. This condition typically involves a decrease in bicarbonate as the body tries to buffer the excess hydrogen ions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lactic Acidosis: This condition occurs when lactate levels increase in the bloodstream during tissue hypoxia, commonly seen in shock or severe dehydration, and results in HAGMA.

 

Option C. Diabetic Ketoacidosis: In DKA, the body produces high levels of blood acids called ketones, which lead to HAGMA.

 

Option D. Salicylate Poisoning: In salicylate toxicity, especially at higher doses, metabolic acidosis occurs due to uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation, leading to HAGMA. Initially, salicylate stimulates the respiratory center causing a respiratory alkalosis, which can be followed by metabolic acidosis at higher doses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal disorders typically cause non-anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) due to an inability to excrete acid or conserve bicarbonate, rather than high anion gap acidosis seen in conditions like lactic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis, and salicylate poisoning.

choices.text: Hip Circumference
HDL
Glucose
Hypertension

questions.text: Which is not considered in the diagnosis of Metabolic syndrome: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hip Circumference

 

Option A: Hip circumference is not typically considered as a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome. The criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome usually include a combination of factors such as central obesity (usually measured by waist circumference), elevated blood pressure, elevated fasting glucose, high triglycerides, and low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein): HDL cholesterol is considered in the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome. Low levels of HDL are one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option C. Glucose: Elevated fasting glucose or impaired glucose tolerance is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome.

 

Option D. Hypertension: High blood pressure is one of the criteria for diagnosing metabolic syndrome. Hypertension is considered a component of metabolic syndrome.

 

Educational objective:

 

Metabolic syndrome is a cluster of conditions that increase the risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. The diagnosis of metabolic syndrome involves the assessment of specific criteria related to various health parameters. The objective is to identify individuals at higher risk for these conditions so that preventive measures can be taken.

questions.text: In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), which of the following findings would be atypical for a classification of 'very severe’? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neovascularization of disc

 

  • In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), it is important to understand the typical and atypical findings associated with the disease severity:

 

This is considered an atypical finding for NPDR and is generally associated with proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). NVD indicates a more severe and advanced stage where new blood vessels grow on the optic disc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous Bleeding: In NPDR, more common findings are microaneurysms or dot hemorrhages.

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhages: Common in NPDR, especially as the severity increases. These hemorrhages are often small and scattered throughout the retina.

 

Option D. Microaneurysm: A hallmark and typically one of the earliest signs of NPDR. These are small, round, red spots seen on fundoscopic examination caused by capillary dilatation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When examining a patient with diabetic retinopathy, finding neovascularization would necessitate reclassification to proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which requires different management strategies including possible laser therapy or anti-VEGF injections to prevent further vision loss.

questions.text:
Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following options: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

 

Non-scarring alopecia is characterized by hair loss without destruction of the hair follicle, allowing for the potential regrowth of hair. The options provided include three conditions that typically result in non-scarring alopecia:

 

1. Alopecia areata: An autoimmune disorder that causes patchy hair loss on the scalp and other parts of the body. This condition is non-scarring, as the hair follicles are not destroyed and hair can regrow if the underlying autoimmune process is controlled or subsides.

 

2. Telogen effluvium: A condition characterized by widespread thinning of the hair, often triggered by a significant stress event, illness, or hormonal change. It results from a large number of hair follicles entering the resting phase (telogen) simultaneously. Recovery is possible once the triggering event is resolved, and the follicles remain intact.

 

3. Androgenic alopecia: Commonly known as male or female pattern baldness, this is a genetic condition influenced by androgens (hormones). It involves hair thinning in a characteristic pattern and is non-scarring, as the hair follicles gradually produce thinner, shorter hairs but are not completely destroyed.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a form of scarring alopecia. It involves a progressive, symmetrical band of hair loss at the front of the scalp along with loss of eyebrows. The scarring means that the hair follicles are permanently destroyed, preventing the regrowth of hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional Information

questions.text: You are working as an ER physician, and a patient with a laceration has just been brought in. You decide to use the interrupted suturing technique to close the wound. As you prepare to suture, you recall that the angle of needle placement is crucial for optimal wound closure. What is the correct angle of needle placement for interrupted suturing technique? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 90 degrees

 

This is the correct angle because inserting the needle perpendicular to the skin (at a 90-degree angle) ensures optimal tissue eversion and approximation of the wound edges. It allows for consistent depth and distance from the wound edge on both the entry and exit points of the needle, which is crucial for the interrupted suturing technique to effectively close the wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To properly execute interrupted sutures, it is recommended that the needle is inserted and exited the skin at a right angle (90 degrees). It is important to rotate the needle through the tissue to prevent unnecessary enlargement of the needle hole. The distance between the entry point of the suture and the edge of the wound should be nearly equal to the depth of tissue that is being sutured. Additionally, it is advised to leave a distance that is twice this measurement between two consecutive sutures.

choices.text: A-1, B-3, C-2, D-4
A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2
A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4
A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1

questions.text: Match the following:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

The chronology of eruption of secondary dentition or permanent teeth is as follows:

 

  • Canine: Erupts at 11-12 years (A-3)
  • Lateral incisor: Erupts at 8-9 years (B-2)
  • First molar: Erupts at 6-7 years (C-1)
  • Third molar: Erupts at 17-25 years (D-4)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronology of eruption of secondary dentition or permanent teeth:
 

 

Mnemonic: Mother Is In Pain Papa Can Make Medicine

questions.text: Recommended HPV vaccination schedule for 9- to 14-year-olds according to WHO SAGE guidelines is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 or 2 doses

 

Recommended Schedule:

 

  • One or Two-Dose Schedule:
    • One dose is considered sufficient for healthy individuals aged 9–14 years.
    • Alternatively, a two-dose schedule may be administered, with the second dose given 6–12 months after the first.

 

Key Considerations:

 

  • Primary Target Group: Girls aged 9–14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.
  • Immunocompromised Individuals: Should receive at least two doses, and where feasible, three doses, regardless of age.
  • Vaccination of Boys: While the primary focus is on girls, vaccinating boys is recommended where feasible and affordable to enhance herd immunity and prevent HPV-related diseases in males. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO SAGE guidelines recommend 1 or 2 doses of HPV vaccine for 9- to 14-year-olds.

questions.text: What is the skin manifestation seen resulting from drugs used to treat amebic dysentery? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fixed drug eruption

 

  • Among the various medication available, metronidazole is drug used to treat amebic dysentery most frequently & it is associated with fixed drug eruption (FDE), which is a drug-induced skin manifestation.
  • Metronidazole can cause maculopapular rashes, but it also has a higher likelihood of causing a fixed drug eruption.
  • Fixed drug eruptions/ reactions are characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions. They can cause a burning sensation and appear on the lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa.
  • They frequently appear alone or in small groups and return to the same spot. On re-exposure to the harmful drug, however, new lesions may develop on various body parts. FDE is a form of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Some of the most frequently prescribed medications that cause FDE are NSAIDs Tetracyclines and paracetamol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urticaria

 

  • While urticaria (hives) can be a common reaction to many drugs, it is not specifically associated with the treatment of amoebic dysentery.
  • Urticaria is characterized by raised, often itchy, red or skin-colored wheals on the surface of the skin as shown below.

 

 

  • It is usually as an immediate hypersensitivity reaction.

 

Option C. Maculopapular rash

 

  • A maculopapular rash is a skin change that can occur with many conditions or as a reaction to various drugs.
  • It is characterized by a flat, red area on the skin that is covered with small confluent bumps as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • While this type of rash can be seen with many types of medications, it is not the most characteristic skin manifestation resulting from drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery.

 

Option D. Atopic dermatitis

 

  • Atopic dermatitis is a chronic skin condition characterized by itchy, inflamed skin.
  • It is not a drug-induced condition but rather a type of eczema that has a strong genetic predisposition and is commonly associated with allergic diseases.
  • It is not typically associated with amoebic dysentery treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fixed drug eruption is a skin manifestation commonly associated with the drugs used to treat amoebic dysentery (Metronidazole).
  • While other skin reactions can occur due to various drugs, fixed drug eruptions are characterized by recurrent lesions at the same site upon re-exposure to a particular drug.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 118 page no 118.11-12

questions.text: A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following US finding is seen. Identify the defect? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anencephaly

 

The given ultrasound image shows an open neural tube defect in the calvaria (skull), which is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Anencephaly: Results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.
    • Ultrasound Signs:
      • Frog eye sign: Absence of cranial calvaria with prominent orbits, resembling the face of a frog.
      • Shower cap sign: Absence of the cranium leading to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue, resembling a shower cap and giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.
    • Prevention: Can be prevented by pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation (5 mg) for at least 3 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: Congenital herniation of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall covered by a membrane. It is different from gastroschisis.

 

Option C. Cystic hygroma: Lymphangioma occurring in the head-neck region.

 

Option D. Encephalocele: Protrusion of the brain and membranes through a cranial defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly is an open neural tube defect characterized by the absence of the cranial calvaria and prominent orbits, detectable by ultrasound as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. It can be prevented with pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 201, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg471

questions.text: Match the following drugs in column A to their site of action in column B?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2


The correct match is as follows:

 

 

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts at the proximal convoluted tubules.
  • Torsemide is a loop diuretic that acts by inhibiting Na+-K+-2Cl channel at the thick ascending limb of the Loop of Henle.
  • Chlorthalidone, a thiazide-like diuretic, inhibits the Na-CI symporter in the distal convoluted tubule.
  • Vasopressin, or ADH, is secreted by the posterior pituitary and mainly acts on the collecting duct, and increases the reabsorption of free water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetazolamide acts on the proximal convoluted tubule, Torsemide on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, Chlorothiazide on the distal convoluted tubule, and Vasopressin on the collecting duct.

questions.text: Causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis are all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

 

  • ABO incompatibility is an immune-mediated cause of hemolytic disease of the newborn, but it is not typically associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Non-immune hydrops is often caused by factors other than immune reactions, such as congenital heart defects, infections, or chromosomal anomalies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congestive cardiac failure: Congestive cardiac failure can contribute to non-immune hydrops fetalis. Conditions affecting the fetal heart can lead to fluid accumulation, resulting in hydrops.

 

Option C. Parvovirus infection: Parvovirus infection is a known cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Parvovirus can affect the developing fetus and lead to severe anemia, causing fluid accumulation.

 

Option D. Chromosomal anomalies: Chromosomal anomalies, such as Turner syndrome or trisomy 21, are associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Abnormalities in fetal development, including those affecting multiple organ systems, can lead to fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the various causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Understand that conditions such as congestive cardiac failure, infections (e.g., parvovirus), and chromosomal anomalies can contribute to the development of hydrops in the absence of immune-mediated factors. Be aware that ABO incompatibility is not a typical cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: Which biopsy technique is used to diagnose Marjolin ulcer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wedge biopsy

 

Wedge biopsy involves the removal of a small, wedge-shaped piece of tissue from the border of an ulcer. This technique is particularly useful in diagnosing Marjolin ulcers because it is the site where squamous cell carcinomas have maximum proliferation, leading to “everted edge”. Marjolin ulcers often develop in areas of previously injured or scarred skin, and a wedge biopsy can provide a representative sample for histopathological examination to confirm the presence of malignancy.


Other Options:

 

Option B. Excision biopsy: Excision biopsy is the technique of choice for a cervical lymph node pathology, in which the entire lymph node is surgically removed for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Core needle biopsy: Core needle biopsy is preferred for sampling soft tissue sarcomas, in which a small sample of tissue is removed using a large bore needle for examination.

 

Option D. USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC): USG-guided fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the technique of choice for a solitary thyroid nodule, in which a small amount of thyroid tissue is aspirated using a thin needle and examined under a microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A wedge biopsy is the preferred and commonly used biopsy technique to diagnose Marjolin ulcers because it allows for the examination of tissue from the ulceration site.

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Electron microscopy

 

  • Among the given options, electron microscopy will be the least useful in assessing nasal mucociliary clearance.
  • Electron microscopy -  can detect structural and functional abnormalities of cilia but do not detect any other abnormalities interfering with nasal mucociliary clearance. It is used to visualize the detailed architecture of cilia, which can help identify defects in ciliary structure responsible for impaired mucociliary transport, but it does not measure the actual transport or clearance function.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saccharin Test: This is a straightforward clinical test where a small amount of saccharin is placed on the nasal mucosa, and the time it takes for the subject to taste the sweetness is measured. This time reflects the mucociliary clearance rate.

 

Option C. Charcoal Powder Method: Involves placing a small amount of charcoal powder in the nose and timing how long it takes for it to appear in the pharynx, similarly assessing the clearance capability of the mucociliary apparatus.

 

Option D. Scintigraphy: This nuclear medicine test uses a small amount of radioactive material to track and record mucociliary transport and clearance, providing both functional and anatomical information about the nasal and sinus mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Test for mucociliary clearance is:
    • Saccharin with or without color test in vivo -   Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance.
    • Radioisotope transport testing in vivo
    • Measuring ciliary activity in vitro
    • Nasal nitric oxide -  Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value
    • Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction
    • Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results.
    • The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.

questions.text: The hormone that does not play a role in the growth of the fetus is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growth hormone.

 

Fetal growth is a complex process regulated by various hormones, but growth hormone does not play a significant role in this process during fetal life. The primary hormones involved in fetal growth include insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Insulin: Insulin is crucial for fetal growth, especially during the third trimester. It plays a key role in promoting the storage of nutrients and the growth of fetal tissues, particularly adipose tissue and muscle.
  • Thyroxine: Fetal production of thyroxine begins around the 12th week of gestation. Thyroxine is vital for the development of the central nervous system and overall growth and differentiation of tissues.
  • Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids are essential towards the end of gestation, particularly for the maturation of organs such as the lungs, liver, and gastrointestinal tract. They help prepare the fetus for life outside the womb by stimulating the production of surfactant in the lungs and facilitating the maturation of other critical systems.
  • Growth Hormone: Unlike in postnatal life, where growth hormone is a key regulator of growth, its role in fetal growth is minimal. Fetal growth is largely driven by insulin and other growth factors rather than growth hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin and Option C. Thyroxine: Both are crucial for fetal growth, regulating tissue growth and differentiation, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Glucocorticoids: These hormones are essential for the maturation of fetal organs before birth, particularly in the liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, which is primarily regulated by insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

choices.text: Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery
Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

questions.text: What is the blood supply of the structure marked with the arrow in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery

 

The corpus callosum is the largest fibre pathway in the brain. The corpus callosum is composed of the rostrum, genu, trunk or body, and splenium.

 

The corpus callosum is a large bundle of nerve fibers that connects the two hemispheres of the brain and allows for communication between them. It is supplied with blood by the anterior cerebral artery and the anterior communicating artery, which are both branches of the internal carotid artery.

 

The anterior cerebral artery supplies blood to the front and top of the brain, including the medial surface of the cerebral hemispheres, which is where the corpus callosum is located. The anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and provides additional blood supply to the corpus callosum. Damage to the corpus callosum, such as from a stroke or traumatic brain injury, can disrupt communication between the two hemispheres and lead to a range of neurological symptoms depending on the location and severity of the damage.

 

The corpus callosum is the major commissural pathway connecting the cerebral hemispheres that receives its blood supply from anterior communicating artery, pericallosal artery, and posterior pericallosal artery”.

 

“Pericallosal artery is formed by branches of from anterior and posterior cerebral arteries (Mainly anterior cerebral artery). Pericallosal arteries which are derived from anterior cerebral arteries supply the anterior 4/5th of corpus callosum and posterior 1/5th is supplied by pericallosal artery derived from posterior cerebral artery.”

 

Since the arrow is near the posterior end of body answer is ACommA + ACA
If the arrow was near the anterior end, answer will be ACommA + ACA
If the arrow is on splenium, the answer will be ACA + PCA
 

 

 

   

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery: The anterior cerebral artery does supply the corpus callosum, but the middle cerebral artery does not play a significant role in its blood supply.

 

Option B. Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery: While the anterior cerebral artery supplies the corpus callosum, the posterior cerebral artery primarily supplies the posterior parts of the brain, including the occipital lobes. It doesn't contribute significantly to the blood supply of the corpus callosum.

 

Option D. Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery: Neither the middle cerebral artery nor the posterior cerebral artery is the primary supplier of blood to the corpus callosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corpus callosum's blood supply is primarily provided by the anterior cerebral artery, with additional support from the anterior communicating artery. This knowledge is crucial in understanding potential impacts of circulatory issues within the brain, such as strokes, which could affect interhemispheric communication.

choices.text: White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils

questions.text: An autopsy was performed on a woman who was reportedly discovered near a village lake. Among the listed factors, which one does not indicate drowning prior to death:(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Washerwoman's hands and feet

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet just indicates that body was immersed in water. It does not specify whether the person died due to drowning or not. It occurs due to infiltration of water into the outer layers of the skin, which will occur irrespective whether the person died due to drowning or the body was thrown in water after death.

 

 

If a body is recovered from water, the there are two different kind of signs to look for:

 

  1. Signs of Antemortem Drowning: These will indicate that person died due to drowning.
  2. Signs of Immersion: These will only indicate that the body was in water.

 

Signs of Antemortem Drowning (in descending order of accuracy):

 

  • Grass or weeds tightly held in hands (cadaveric Spasm): Surest sign
  • Drowning Froth Over Mouth and Nose and in air passages: Second best sign
  • Emphysema Aquosum (overinflated lungs)
  • Presence of sand / mud etc. in respiratory passages especially in terminal part
  • Diatom test
  • Presence of water especially if mixed with mud / sand etc. in Stomach or intestines
  • Paltauff Haemorrhage (Subpleural Haemorrhage)
  • Gettler’s test

 

Signs of Immersion

 

  • Washerwoman’s hand / feet
  • Cutis anserina=goose skin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water in stomach: This suggests that the person was alive when entering the water and swallowed water, indicating antemortem drowning.

 

Option C. White leathery foam around mouth and nostrils: This foam, often referred to as "drowning froth," is a strong indicator of antemortem drowning as it forms when water mixes with air and mucus in the airways.

 

Option D. Positive diatom test: The presence of diatoms in the organs indicates that the person inhaled water while still alive, allowing these microscopic algae to enter the bloodstream and be deposited in various tissues, thus confirming antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's hands and feet indicate immersion in water but do not specify drowning as the cause of death, unlike other indicators such as water in the stomach, white leathery foam, and a positive diatom test, which strongly suggest antemortem drowning.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an immune checkpoint inhibitor? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cetuximab 

 

Cetuximab is a monoclonal antibody against EGFR (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor). It is used in the treatment of Colorectal and Head and Neck Cancers. It is not an immune check point inhibitor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and are used for the treatment of advanced melanoma and classical Hodgkin lymphoma.
