Option B. Pembrolizumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor

- 1 (PD-1) and are used for the treatment of advanced melanoma.

 

Option C. Atezolimumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It acts by inhibiting programmed death-ligand - 1 (PDL-1) and is used for the treatment of urothelial, breast and non-small cell lung cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important immune check point inhibitors include:

 

New:                Nivolumab

Drugs:              Durvalumab

Act:                  Avelumab

At:                   Atezolizumab

Immune:          Ipilimumab

Check:             Cemiplimab

Point:               Pembrolizumab

questions.text: In the figure shown below, mechanism of action of valproate is best represented by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

Mechanisms of Action of Sodium Valproate

 

  1. Enhancement of GABA Activity:
    • Valproate increases the levels of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), an inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain. This is achieved primarily by stimulating the enzyme glutamic acid decarboxylase that helps in formation of GABA from glutamic acid. Valproate also acts by inhibiting GABA transaminase, the enzyme responsible for GABA breakdown, leading to increased GABA availability.
  2. Inhibition of Voltage-Gated Sodium Channels:
    • Valproate modulates voltage-gated sodium channels in the neurons. By prolonging the recovery of these channels from inactivation, valproate reduces the high-frequency repetitive firing of action potentials.
  3. Inhibition of T-Type Calcium Channels:
    • Valproate also affects T-type calcium channels, particularly in thalamic neurons. By inhibiting these channels, it reduces the rhythmic cortical discharges that are often seen in absence seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B represents the mechanism of action of drugs like gabapentin and pregabalin. These act by increasing the release of GABA.

 

Option C. C represents the mechanism of action of tiagabine. It acts by inhibiting the reuptake of GABA.

 

Option D. D is site of action of benzodiazepines like diazepam and lorazepam.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valproate increases GABA levels by stimulating the enzyme GAD (glutamic acid decarboxylase) to convert glutamate into GABA and by inhibiting GABA transaminase, preventing the breakdown of GABA.

questions.text:
What are the indicators that suggest CPR is of high quality? (INICET May 2023)

 

1. Chest compression at a rate of 100-120/minute

2. Breathing rate of 20-25/minute

3. Depth of compression should be 5-6 cm

4. Allow chest recoil
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

 

Explanation:

 

High-Quality CPR Indicators:

 

1. Chest Compression Rate: Chest compressions should be performed at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.

 

3. Depth of Compression: Compressions should have a depth of 5-6 centimeters (2-2.4 inches).

 

4. Chest Recoil: It is essential to allow the chest to fully recoil after each compression to ensure adequate filling of the heart between compressions. If an advanced airway, such as an endotracheal tube or supraglottic airway device, is in place, the recommended ventilation rate is 10 breaths per minute.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 3 only: While a compression depth of 5-6 cm is correct, a breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not part of the indicators for high-quality CPR.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 3, 4: Although chest compression rate, depth, and recoil are correct indicators, the breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not recommended for high-quality CPR.

 

Option D. 1 only: While the correct chest compression rate is part of high-quality CPR, other factors like compression depth and chest recoil are also crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Effective CPR involves chest compressions performed at a rate between 100 to 120 compressions per minute and at a depth of 5 to 6 centimeters, allowing the chest to fully recoil after each compression. The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 without an advanced airway, and 10 breaths per minute if an advanced airway is in place.

choices.text: Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic
Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic
Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic.

 

During an extended right colectomy, the ileocolic, right colic, and trunk of the middle colic vessels are typically resected to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma.

 

The stem of the middle colic and the left colic artery are not resected during an extended right colectomy as they are not directly involved with the blood supply to the proximal transverse colon. It is important to note that the surgical management of colon cancer depends on the stage and location of the tumor and may involve various surgical techniques, including colectomy and lymphadenectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of radical colectomies and vessels ligated:

 

  1. Right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic artery
  2. Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and stem/origin of middle colic artery
  3. Left hemicolectomy: Left colic and sigmoid artery

choices.text: A, B & C
A, B, C & D

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in Gout? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion

B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint

C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways

D. Aspirin is used as it is most powerful NSAID
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A, B & C

 

Options A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion: This statement remains correct. Aspirin at low doses can decrease uric acid excretion, potentially worsening gout. Therefore, it is generally not recommended in the management of gout.

 

Options B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint: Diclofenac is commonly used in the management of gout due to its anti-inflammatory properties. It gets concentrated in joints and its effect in reducing inflammation and pain in gout is beneficial.

 

Options C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways: Indomethacin is indeed used in the treatment of gout. It is an NSAID that works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins. It has multiple pathways of action including inhibition of COX and decrease in rate of phagocytosis of urate crystals.

 

Other Options:

 

Options D. Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAID: This statement is incorrect for reasons previously mentioned. Aspirin, particularly at low doses, is not recommended for gout due to its potential to increase serum uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The preferred treatment for an acute gout attack is an NSAID (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug), such as indomethacin.
  • A typical first-line treatment for gout is indomethacin. Besides suppressing prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also reduce rate of crystal phagocytosis.
  • Furthermore, intraarticular steroids like methylprednisolone or triamcinolone may be given.
  • Aspirin is not utilized because it promotes renal retention of uric acid.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve passing through the given structure: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. IV

 

Explanation:

 

In the given image, the dorsal aspect of the brainstem is marked and the cranial nerve that is passing there is the trochlear nerve (CN IV).

 

Trochlear nerve

 

  • Origin : The trochlear nerve is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal (posterior) aspect of the brain. Specifically, it originates from the dorsal surface of the midbrain, below the inferior colliculus.
  • Exit proceed to the superior orbital fissure to enter the orbit.
  • Function: It is a motor nerve that innervates a single extraocular muscle, the superior oblique muscle. The primary action of the superior oblique muscle is to intort (rotate inward), depress, and abduct the eyeball.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve (III):

 

  • Origin: The oculomotor nerve originates in the anterior aspect of the midbrain. Specifically, its fibers arise from the oculomotor nucleus, which is located in the superior colliculus of the midbrain.
  • Exit Point: After emerging from the midbrain, it exits the brainstem at the level of the interpeduncular fossa (the space between the cerebral peduncles).
  • Function: It innervates most of the muscles controlling eye movements. It also contains parasympathetic fibers that are involved in pupil constriction and the lens's accommodation.

 

Option B. Facial Nerve (VII):

 

  • Origin: The facial nerve arises from the pons. Specifically, its fibers come from the facial nerve nucleus.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle, between the pons and the medulla. It exits lateral to the abducens nerve and medial to the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).
  • Function: The facial nerve controls the muscles of facial expression. It also has taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and carries parasympathetic fibers to salivary and lacrimal glands.
     

Option D. Abducens Nerve (VI):

 

  • Origin: The abducens nerve originates in the pons. Its fibers arise from the abducens nucleus, which is located in the dorsal pons near the floor of the fourth ventricle.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the ventral surface of the brainstem at the junction between the pons and the medulla, in the groove between the pons and the pyramid of the medulla.
  • Function: It innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve is the fourth cranial nerve that originates in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus from the trochlear nuclei. It is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the brainstem's dorsal surface and has the longest intracranial course.

 

The main actions of superior oblique are:

 

  • Depression in adducted position- Patients with trochlear nerve palsy have difficulty in looking downwards when eyes are in the adducted position.
  • Abduction
  • Intorsion of the eyeball.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of subcortical dementia?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pick's disease

 

To approach this question, we need to differentiate between cortical and subcortical dementias.

 

This is a type of frontotemporal dementia and is cortical. It primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes. Memory may be preserved in the early stages, but personality and language changes are prominent. Therefore, it doesn't fall under the subcortical category, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's primarily affects the basal ganglia in the brain, which is a subcortical structure. The primary symptoms are motoric (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia), but dementia can develop in the later stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Huntington's disease: This is a genetic disorder that affects the basal ganglia, especially the caudate nucleus, which is also a subcortical structure. Cognitive decline and psychiatric symptoms are common.

 

Option D. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation in the body, including the brain. The basal ganglia is one of the primary areas affected, making the dementia subcortical in nature.

 

Given the options, Pick's disease is the only cortical dementia, making it the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 24.

questions.text: Identify the given ECG? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Torsade’s de pointes

 

Torsade’s de pointes is characterized by a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with varying QRS complex amplitudes and a twisting around the baseline.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Characterized by a chaotic and irregular waveform without identifiable QRS complexes.
 

Option C. Atrial flutter: Shows a sawtooth pattern of atrial activity.
 

Option D. Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia: Shows uniform QRS complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Torsade’s de pointes are a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with a characteristic twisting pattern.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is the new FDA approved immune check point inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pembrolizumab

 

The new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium is Pembrolizumab.

 

Pembrolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against PD-1 receptor (Programmed Death Receptor) that can be used for many cancers including endometrial carcinoma. Some of the other cancers where it is useful are:

 

  • Metastatic urothelial cancer
  • Refractory melanoma
  • Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Merkel cell cancer
  • Chemotherapy Refractory Head and Neck Cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab: is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and is used for the treatment of advanced melanoma and relapsed/refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option C. Trastuzumab: is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the HER2 receptor. It is used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Option D. Ipilimumab: is a monoclonal antibody that binds to cytotoxic T lymphocyte-associated Protein 4 (CTLA-4) and is approved for the treatment of late-stage melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pembrolizumab is the new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium. It works by blocking the PD-1 receptor, enhancing the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells. It is also used for treating several other cancers, including metastatic urothelial cancer, refractory melanoma, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Merkel cell cancer, and chemotherapy-refractory head and neck cancer.
